text:
Metropolitan Club, 5th Avenue, north east corner of 60th Street

May 1, 1894.

Photo by J.S. Johnston, New York
Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue at N.E. corner of 60th Street. 1914.

Central Park Entrances: The Grand Army Plaza and its Sherman statue.  Buildings in the background are on the east side of Fifth Avenue, E. 60th to 61st Streets; the Metropolitan Club
occupying, being at the right.

About 1915.

Gift of Urbrock Collection

12-14 East 60th Street, south side, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. This building is the Bellaire Apartment House Hotel. William Lawrence Bottomley is the architect.

About 1920.

A. E. Sproul.

Fifth Ave. east side, north from 60th Street, showing a portion of Central Park in the foreground.
February 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - 5th Avenue - 60th Street
Fifth Avenue - 60th Street - 64th Street, looking northeast

text:
No. 1, NRA Parade. A group of the Warner Brothers-Vitaphone employees awaiting their turn in the parade. In June 1933, during the fourth month of Franklin D. Roosevelt's administration, the National Industrial Recovery Act (NIRA) was passed by Congress and signed by the President. This act delegated to the President the right to draft codes for industries, which established, among other things, minimum wages and maximum hours. Under the provisions of this act, President Roosevelt created the National Recovery Administration (NRA), with General Hugh S. Johnson as Administrator. Industries were invited to draft their own codes and submit them to General Johnson and his staff for approval. Pending the adoption of these codes, all businesses, big and small, were invited to subscribe to a blanket code draft by Roosevelt, and known as the NRA (President's Recovery Agreement). All those who did so received a token of compliance to poster bearing the Blue Eagle clothing in the foot of the cog-wheels of industry, and in the other streaks of lightning. During its early days, NRA was greeted with almost fanatical, not to say hysterical, support by both business and labor. Only from the communists and a few other minor radicals did it receive bitter denunciation. In New York City this enthusiasm expressed itself in the form of a monster parade, surpassing in size the other parades. It formed at Washington Square, and marched north on Fifth Avenue to 60th Street, where it disbanded. The first group of marchers left Washington Square around two o'clock in the afternoon and reached midnight before the last marchers reached 66th Street and the parade disbanded. The picture gives a glimpse of the individual portions of the parade; but it is impossible to get any idea of its size or the enthusiasm of the participants. Anyone who has interest in the history of NRA will find it a most interesting chapter. Within six months the popularity of NRA began to wane. An attempt was made to revive the NRA enthusiasm and the slogan 'Buy under the Blue Eagle' was used, but it was unsuccessful. In the Schechter case, the Supreme Court declared the NRA codes unconstitutional. The NRA was popularily known as 'Roosevelt's New Deal.' The NRA still exists, but without the codes it has little meaning. All Blue Eagles have been repealed, and it is a penal offense to display one. The codes have been held to be violations of the minimum wages, maximum hours, and fair practice clauses. September 13, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 2, NRA Parade. A close-up of one of the Warner Brothers-Vitaphone girls waiting in West 10th Street for her group to swing into the parade. September 13, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 3, NRA Parade. Employees of Loew's theatres awaiting their turn in the parade. September 13, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - N. R. A. [National Recovery Administration] Parade, No. 1-3.

text:
Central Park: The Sheridan Monument in a small square at the southeastern corner of the Park, that technically is called Grand Army Plaza. The photographer is viewing northeastward to show buildings on the east side of Fifth Ave., at 60th Street.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

Fifth Avenue, at the S.E. corner of E. 60th Street as viewed eastward from the Grand Army Plaza. The 10 story corner building bears numbers '786-7', while adjoining same is a studio structure bearing No. 784-5. To the left appears a portion of the Metropolitan Club occupying a site at the N.E. corner. Also shown is an eastward view of the south side of E. 60th Street from Fifth to Madison Avenues.

April 23, 1938.

P.L. Sperr
